name: Language acquisition
description: Within the Arts and Humanities / Languages domain, Language acquisition is the study of the structure and composition of languages when taught as second or foreign languages (i.e., for non-native speakers). It can include related culture, literature, linguistics, and phonetics if tied to the specific language being acquired. Classical languages are also included here. [cite: 99, 100, 101]

name: Classical languages
description: The study of ancient languages such as Latin or Classical Greek, treated as foreign languages for acquisition purposes within Language acquisition. [cite: 100, 102]

name: Exogenous languages
description: The study of foreign languages, i.e., languages not native to the speaker or the region, as part of Language acquisition. [cite: 102]

name: Foreign languages
description: The study and learning of languages other than one's native tongue, a core component of Language acquisition. [cite: 99, 102]

name: Interpretation
description: The skill and practice of orally translating speech from one language to another, studied within Language acquisition. [cite: 102, 103]

name: Phonetics
description: The study of speech sounds, their production, and perception, often included in Language acquisition programmes when related to a specific language being learned. [cite: 99, 102]

name: Second languages, for example English as a second language
description: The study of a language by non-native speakers in an environment where that language is spoken, a focus of Language acquisition. [cite: 99, 102]

name: Sign language
description: The study and acquisition of languages that use manual communication and body language to convey meaning, included in Language acquisition. [cite: 102]

name: Sign language interpreting
description: The skill of facilitating communication between users of spoken language and users of sign language, studied within Language acquisition. [cite: 102]

name: Translation
description: The process of rendering written text from one language into another, a skill developed in Language acquisition programmes. [cite: 102, 103]
